Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Minimally Invasive and Standard Total Knee Arthroplasty

Background: Minimally invasive surgical (MIS) techniques in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) aim to preserve quadriceps strength postoperatively. This study evaluates whether MIS TKA results in greater knee strength compared to standard TKA.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a single center. Participants were adults eligible for TKA, matched for age, weight, height, BMI, sex, and surgically treated side. Fifty-two patients were randomised to receive either MIS or standard TKA. The primary outcome was knee extensor torque, measured preoperatively and at 8 weeks postoperatively using isokinetic tests. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Results: Baseline extensor torques were 57 Nm for MIS and 53 Nm for standard TKA. At 8 weeks, mean postoperative extensor torques were 47 Nm for MIS and 45 Nm for standard TKA. The postoperative-to-preoperative ratios were 0.8 for both groups. The extensor-flexor torque ratios were similar. No significant differences were observed in knee scores, alignment, ROM, tourniquet and operating times, or hospital length of stay. Adverse events were not reported.

Interpretation: MIS TKA does not significantly enhance postoperative quadriceps strength compared to standard TKA. The study was registered under trial number [insert trial registration number]. Funding was provided by [insert funding source].
